T1003.name: OS Credential Dumping
T1003.description: Adversaries may attempt to dump credentials from the operating system.

T1003.001.name: LSASS Memory
T1003.001.description: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in LSASS process memory.

T1021.001.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
T1021.001.description: Adversaries may use RDP to log into a computer using the Remote Desktop Protocol.

T1027.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
T1027.description: Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze.

T1036.name: Masquerading
T1036.description: Adversaries may attempt to manipulate features of their artifacts to make them appear legitimate.

T1036.007.name: Double File Extension
T1036.007.description: Adversaries may abuse a double extension in the filename to disguise the actual file type.

T1053.005.name: Scheduled Task
T1053.005.description: Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution.

T1059.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
T1059.description: Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands.

T1059.001.name: PowerShell
T1059.001.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.

T1070.001.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
T1070.001.description: Adversaries may clear Windows Event Logs to hide the activity of an intrusion.

T1071.001.name: Web Protocols
T1071.001.description: Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols associated with web traffic.

T1071.004.name: DNS
T1071.004.description: Adversaries may communicate using the DNS application layer protocol.

T1074.001.name: Local Data Staging
T1074.001.description: Adversaries may stage collected data in a central location on the local system.

T1078.name: Valid Accounts
T1078.description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of existing accounts.

T1090.003.name: Multi-hop Proxy
T1090.003.description: Adversaries may chain together multiple proxies to disguise the source of malicious traffic.

T1095.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
T1095.description: Adversaries may use a non-application layer protocol for communication between host and C2 server.

T1105.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
T1105.description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment.

T1106.name: Native API
T1106.description: Adversaries may interact with the native OS application programming interface (API) to execute behaviors.

T1136.001.name: Local Account
T1136.001.description: Adversaries may create a local account to maintain access to victim systems.

T1204.002.name: Malicious File
T1204.002.description: An adversary may rely upon a user opening a malicious file in order to gain execution.

T1218.name: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
T1218.description: Adversaries may bypass process and/or signature-based defenses by proxying execution of malicious content.

T1543.003.name: Windows Service
T1543.003.description: Adversaries may create or modify Windows services to repeatedly execute malicious payloads.

T1547.001.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
T1547.001.description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key.

T1566.001.name: Spearphishing Attachment
T1566.001.description: Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a malicious attachment.

T1568.002.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
T1568.002.description: Adversaries may use DGAs to dynamically identify a destination domain for command and control traffic.

T1571.name: Non-Standard Port
T1571.description: Adversaries may communicate using a protocol and port pairing that are typically not associated.

T1572.name: Protocol Tunneling
T1572.description: Adversaries may tunnel network communications to and from a victim system within a separate protocol.

T1574.name: Hijack Execution Flow
T1574.description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the way operating systems run programs.

kill_chain_phases.name: Initial Access
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to gain initial access to the network

kill_chain_phases.name: Execution
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques that result in adversary-controlled code running on a local or remote system

kill_chain_phases.name: Persistence
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to maintain access to systems across restarts

kill_chain_phases.name: Privilege Escalation
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network

kill_chain_phases.name: Defense Evasion
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to avoid detection throughout the compromise

kill_chain_phases.name: Credential Access
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques for stealing credentials like account names and passwords

kill_chain_phases.name: Discovery
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to gain knowledge about the system and internal network

kill_chain_phases.name: Lateral Movement
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to enter and control remote systems on a network

kill_chain_phases.name: Collection
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to gather data of interest from the target environment

kill_chain_phases.name: Command and Control
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used for communicating with compromised systems to control them

kill_chain_phases.name: Exfiltration
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to steal data from the network

kill_chain_phases.name: Impact
kill_chain_phases.description: Techniques used to disrupt availability or compromise integrity
